questions.text: Knowledge that others find valuable and seek from me is ...
questions.principle: Knowledge becomes capital when others value it

answers.4: substantial — people regularly seek my perspective
answers.5: abundant — I'm a go-to resource in multiple areas
answers.2: minimal — occasionally helpful in narrow areas
answers.3: developing — I'm becoming known for some things
answers.1: nonexistent — no one comes to me for expertise

questions.text: Mental models and frameworks for navigating new situations are ...

answers.4: substantial — I have reliable tools for most situations
answers.5: comprehensive — I've built an integrated system for thinking
answers.2: basic — a few principles I can apply
answers.3: moderate — helpful frameworks in some domains
answers.1: absent — I figure things out from scratch each time

questions.text: My ability to teach or transfer knowledge is ...

answers.4: good — my knowledge is organized enough to share
answers.5: excellent — I can teach at multiple levels effectively
answers.2: limited — I can teach basics with effort
answers.3: moderate — I can transfer knowledge in some areas
answers.1: poor — I know things but can't explain them

questions.text: Intellectual reserves to draw on vs. always scrambling are ...

answers.4: substantial — I usually have knowledge to apply
answers.5: deep — I've accumulated reserves I can deploy anywhere
answers.2: thin — barely enough for current demands
answers.3: moderate — reserves in some areas, scrambling in others
answers.1: empty — I'm always starting from scratch

questions.text: Insights, systems, or content I've produced that has value beyond my personal use is ...

answers.4: substantial — I've built things others benefit from
answers.5: significant — my thinking has produced lasting value
answers.2: minimal — a few things, nothing significant
answers.3: some — I've created useful things for limited audiences
answers.1: nothing — I haven't produced anything shareable

remediation.advice: Intellectual capital is built through Layer 5 (skill in learning and thinking) applied over time. If you're always scrambling, invest in developing expertise in fewer areas rather than shallow knowledge in many. Depth produces surplus; breadth often produces scarcity.

scripture.text: An intelligent heart acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
